skill.name: doc-coauthoring
skill.description: Guide users through a structured workflow for co-authoring documentation. Use when user wants to write documentation, proposals, technical specs, decision docs, or similar structured content. This workflow helps users efficiently transfer context, refine content through iteration, and verify the doc works for readers. Trigger when user mentions writing docs, creating proposals, drafting specs, or similar documentation tasks.
skill.summary: Guide users through a structured workflow for co-authoring documentation. Use when user wants to wri...

security_audit.summary: Official Anthropic skill containing only procedural documentation workflow guidance with no executable code or external integrations. No security concerns identified.

content.value_statement: This skill guides you through a proven three-stage process for creating high-quality documentation that ensures context is captured, content is refined iteratively, and the final document works for readers before publication.
actual_capabilities: Guides through structured three-stage documentation workflow
Facilitates comprehensive context gathering through targeted questions
Brainstorms 5-20 section options based on document type and context
Iteratively refines each section through surgical edits using str_replace
Tests document comprehension with fresh Claude instance (reader testing)
Supports multiple document types: PRDs, design docs, decision docs, RFCs, technical specs
Integrates with available MCP servers for Slack, Teams, Google Drive, SharePoint
Creates document scaffolds using artifacts or markdown files
Generates alt-text for images in shared documents
Provides quality checks for flow, consistency, redundancy, and clarity
limitations: Requires user participation and feedback at each stage
Reader testing with sub-agents only available in Claude Code environment
Cannot directly edit shared documents (only provides content for user to paste)
Integration capabilities depend on enabled MCP servers and connectors
Process is time-intensive compared to freeform writing
Assumes user has domain knowledge to provide initial context
Does not enforce specific organizational documentation standards

use_cases.title: Technical Specification Writing
use_cases.description: Engineers can use this workflow to create comprehensive technical specs that capture architecture decisions, trade-offs, and implementation details in a format that both technical and non-technical stakeholders can understand.

use_cases.title: Decision Documentation
use_cases.description: Teams making important decisions can document the rationale, alternatives considered, and final choice in a way that future team members can understand months or years later.
use_cases.target_user: Product managers, engineering managers, team leads

use_cases.title: Product Requirements Documents
use_cases.description: Product managers can create PRDs that thoroughly capture user needs, success metrics, and feature requirements while ensuring nothing gets lost in translation between teams.

use_cases.title: RFC and Proposal Writing
use_cases.description: Contributors to open source projects or internal teams can draft RFCs that clearly communicate proposed changes and gather structured feedback before implementation.
use_cases.target_user: Open source contributors, platform teams, API designers

prompt_templates.title: Start a Technical Spec
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to write a technical spec for [feature/system name]. Can you guide me through the doc co-authoring workflow?
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need to document a technical implementation with proper architecture decisions and trade-offs

prompt_templates.title: Create a Decision Document
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me write a decision doc about [decision topic]. We need to capture why we're choosing this approach over alternatives.
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need to document an important decision for future reference

prompt_templates.title: Draft a Product Proposal
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to draft a proposal for [product/feature]. Can we use the structured workflow to make sure I don't miss anything important?
prompt_templates.scenario: When proposing a new product or feature to stakeholders

prompt_templates.title: Write an RFC
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to write an RFC for [proposed change]. Let's use the co-authoring workflow to make sure it's thorough.
prompt_templates.scenario: When proposing changes that need community or team review

output_examples.input: I need to write a decision doc about switching our authentication from sessions to JWT tokens
output_examples.output: The skill guides through: (1) Context gathering - asking about current auth system, team size, security requirements, migration concerns; (2) Refinement - building sections on background, decision rationale, alternatives considered, implementation plan, risks, with 5-20 brainstormed points per section; (3) Reader testing - verifying a fresh Claude can correctly answer questions like 'Why are they switching?' and 'What are the security implications?'

best_practices: Start with the section that has the most unknowns rather than writing sequentially
Provide context in whatever format is easiest (stream of consciousness, links, channel references)
Use shorthand when answering clarifying questions to move faster
Be specific about what to change during refinement rather than making direct edits
Complete reader testing before sharing the document with actual stakeholders
Use appendices for depth without bloating the main document
Consider linking the co-authoring conversation in an appendix for transparency
Update the document based on feedback from real readers after publication
anti_patterns: Skipping context gathering and jumping straight to drafting
Directly editing the document instead of indicating changes (prevents Claude from learning your style)
Rushing through brainstorming without considering all relevant angles
Skipping reader testing and assuming the doc is clear because it makes sense to you
Writing all sections sequentially instead of tackling high-uncertainty sections first
Providing vague feedback like 'looks good' instead of specific numbered selections
Ignoring quality checks about removing unnecessary information

faq.question: How long does the full workflow take?
faq.answer: The workflow is thorough and takes longer than freeform writing, but ensures higher quality output. The time varies based on document complexity - a simple decision doc might take 30-60 minutes, while a comprehensive technical spec could take 2-3 hours. The investment pays off by catching issues before others read the document.

faq.question: Can I skip stages if I'm in a hurry?
faq.answer: Yes, you have full agency to adjust the process. If you want to skip stages or work freeform, just let Claude know. However, skipping context gathering or reader testing often leads to documents that confuse readers and require more revisions later.

faq.question: What if I don't have integrations set up for Slack or Google Docs?
faq.answer: The workflow works fine without integrations - you can paste content directly or provide summaries of relevant discussions and documents. Claude will suggest enabling connectors if available, but it's not required.

faq.question: How does reader testing work?
faq.answer: In Claude Code, reader testing happens automatically with sub-agents. In claude.ai, you'll open a fresh conversation and test the document yourself by asking predicted reader questions. This simulates how others will understand the doc without your context.

faq.question: Can I use my own document template?
faq.answer: Absolutely. During context gathering, you can share your template and Claude will structure the workflow around it, creating sections based on your template's structure.

faq.question: What's the difference between artifacts and markdown files?
faq.answer: In environments with artifact support (like claude.ai), Claude creates an interactive artifact you can view and download. In Claude Code or terminal environments, it creates a markdown file in your working directory. Both approaches support the same iterative refinement workflow.

permissions: Optional: MCP server integrations for Slack, Teams, Google Drive, SharePoint
Optional: Sub-agent access for automated reader testing (Claude Code)
